facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 395 of 1959 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 395 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated

facts.text: Appeal from Award dated November 25, 1957 of Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference I.T. No. 24 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 25, 1957 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 24 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellants were originally in the service of Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. (Scindias).

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants were originally in the service of the Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd.  hereinafter called the Scindias .

facts.text: Services of appellants transferred by way of loan to Air Services of India Limited (ASI).

anchor.surface_text: Their services were transferred by way of loan to the Air Services of India Limited  hereinafter referred to as the ASI .

facts.text: ASI was formed in 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The ASI was formed in 1937 and was purchased by the Scindias in 1943

facts.text: ASI purchased by Scindias in 1943.

anchor.surface_text: and was purchased by the Scindias in 1943 and by 1946 was a full subsidiary

facts.text: By 1946, ASI was a full subsidiary of Scindias.

anchor.surface_text: and by 1946 was a full subsidiary of the Scindias.

facts.text: From 1946 to about 1951, large number of Scindias employees transferred to ASI for indefinite periods.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore from 1946 to about 1951, a large number of employees of the, Scindias were transferred to the ASI for indefinite periods.

facts.text: Transferred employees to ASI got same scale of pay and terms and conditions of service as Scindias employees, including bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who were thus transferred to the ASI were to get the same scale of pay as the employees of the Scindias and the same terms and companyditions of service  including bonus whenever the Scindias paid it  were to apply.

facts.text: Scindias retained right to recall loaned employees from ASI.

anchor.surface_text: The Scindias retained the right to recall these loaned employees and it is the case of the appellants that they were entitled to go back

facts.text: Appellants claimed entitlement to go back to Scindias if desired.

anchor.surface_text: to the Scindias if they so desired. Thus the terms and companyditions of service of these loaned employees of the ASI were different

facts.text: Terms of loaned employees different from employees recruited directly by ASI.

anchor.surface_text: were different from those employees of the ASI who were recruited by the ASI itself.

facts.text: Appellants addressed letter to Scindias on April 6, 1953 requesting to be taken back due to nationalisation from June 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: They therefore addressed a letter to the Scindias on April 6, 1953, requesting that as the Government of India intended to nationalise all the air lines in India with effect from 1 June, 1953

facts.text: Scindias replied to appellants' letter on April 24, 1953 explaining clause 20 of Air Corporation Bill applies to all working in ASI.

anchor.surface_text: On April 24, the Scindias sent a reply to this letter in which they pointed out that all persons working in the ASI would be governed by cl. 20 of the Air Corporation Bill of 1953

facts.text: Scindias stated in reply that opting out under proviso to cl.20 would be treated as resignation from Scindias service.

anchor.surface_text: but in case any employee of the ASI whether loaned or otherwise made the option number to join the proposed Corporation, the Scindias would treat them as having resigned from service

facts.text: Union on behalf of appellants replied to Scindias on April 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1953, a reply was sent by the union on behalf of the appellants to the Scindias.

facts.text: Scindias issued circular on May 6, 1953 to all ASI employees including loaned employees.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Scindias issued a circular on May 6,1953, to all the employees under the ASI including the loaned employees

facts.text: Air Corporations Act, No. XXVII of 1953 passed on May 28, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Act was passed on May 28, 1953.

facts.text: Notice sent on June 17, 1953 to each employee of air companies to inform by July 10, 1953 if opting out under proviso to s.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: After the Act was passed, numberice was sent on June 17, 1953, to each employee of all the air companypanies which were being taken over by the proposed Corporation m and he was asked to inform the officer on special duty by July 10, 1953

facts.text: Appellants did not give notice as required by proviso to s.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants admittedly did number give this numberice as required by the proviso to s. 20 1 .

facts.text: Appointed day under s.16 of Act notified as First of August, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: First of August, 1953, was numberified the appointed day under s. 16 of the Act

facts.text: ASI vested in the Corporation on August 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: So on August1, 1953, the ASI vested in the Corporation and s. 20 1  of the Act came into force.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal concluded appellants governed by s.20(1), became employees of Corporation from August 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal came to the companyclusion that, whatever the position of the appellants as loaned staff from the Scindias to the ASI, as they were informed on May 6, 1953, of the exact position by the Scindias and they did number ask for a reference of an industrial dispute immediately thereafter with the Scindias and as they did number exercise the option given to them by the proviso to s. 20 1  before July 10, 1953, they would be governed by s. 20 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants were employed by ASI prior to July 1, 1952 and still in employment immediately before appointed day.

anchor.surface_text: But for the purposes of s. 20 1  we have to see two things namely,  i  whether the officer or employee was employed by the existing air companypany on July 1, 1952, and whether he was still in its employment on the appointed day,  namely, August 1,1953 . Now it is number disputed that the appellants were working in fact for the ASI on July 1, 1952

facts.text: Appellants working for ASI, paid by ASI, control over work by ASI on July 1, 1952 and August 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that they were working for the ASI and were being paid by it their hours of work as well as companytrol over their work was all by the ASI.

facts.text: Court held appellants were employees of ASI in law subject to special terms.

anchor.surface_text: There can in our opinion be numberdoubt that subject to these special terms the appellants were in the employ of the ASI in law. They would therefore be in the employ of the ASI prior to July 1, 1952 and would still be in its employ immediately before August 1, 1953.
Civil Appeal No. 395 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated
Air Corporations Act, No. XXVII of 1953,  hereinafter called the Act  came into force.

concepts.unlisted_description: Act nationalizing air lines, establishing Corporation

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 20 1  of the Act, with which we are concerned, is in these terms- Every officer or other employee of an existing air company  except a director, managing agent, manager or any other person entitled to manage the whole or a substantial part of the business and affairs of the company under a special agreement  employed by that company prior to the first day of July, 1952, and still in its employment immediately before the appointed day shall, in so far as such officer or other employee is employed in connection with the undertaking which has vested in either of the Corporations by virtue of this Act, become as from the appointed date an officer or other employee, as the case may be, of the Corporation in which the undertaking has vested and shall hold his office or service therein by the same tenure, at the same remuneration and upon the same terms and conditions and with the same rights and privileges as to pension and gratuity and other matters as he would have held the same under the existing air company if its undertaking had not vested in the Corporation and shall continue to do so unless and until his employment in the Corporation is terminated or until his remuneration, terms or conditions are duly altered by the Corporation

concepts.interpretation: Applies to loaned employees working for and controlled by air company prior to July 1, 1952 and on appointed day; transfers service to Corporation with continuity unless opted out

concepts.interpretation: Employees can opt out by written notice before fixed date (July 10, 1953); failure to opt results in transfer to Corporation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed facts of working for ASI, paid by ASI, control and direction over work by ASI establish employment despite special terms of pay parity, recall right, and dismissal procedure

holdings.text: they would clearly be governed by s. 20(1). As they did not exercise the option given to them by the proviso to s. 20(1), they became the employees of the Corporation from August 1, 1953, by the terms of the statute

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, they would clearly be governed by s. 20 1 . As they did number exercise the option given to them by the proviso to s. 20 1 , they became the employees of the Corporation from August 1, 1953, by the terms of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfaction of statutory criteria for employment on specified dates combined with failure to opt out under proviso results in automatic transfer to Corporation with service continuity

holdings.text: a contract of service may be transferred by a statutory provision

anchor.surface_text: This observation itself shows that a contract of service may be transferred by a statutory provision but in the present case, as we have already said, there was no compulsory transfer of the contract of service between the existing air companies, and their officers and employees to the Corporation for each of them was given the option not to join the Corporation, if he gave notice to that effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing Nokes v. Doncaster: common law non-assignability of personal service contracts yields to contrary statutory provision; here proviso provides opt-out preventing compulsory transfer

holdings.text: As soon as the appellants became by force of law the employees of the Corporation, as they did so become on August 1, 1953, in the circumstances of this case, they had no further right against the Scindias

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the appellants became by force of law the employees of the Corporation, as they did so become on August 1, 1953, in the circumstances of this case, they had numberfurther right against the Scindias and could not claim to be taken back in their employment on the ground that they were still their employees, in spite of the operation of s. 20 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Operation of s.20(1) transfers employment to Corporation by force of law, extinguishing prior rights against original employer Scindias

holdings.text: the tribunals decision is correct. The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the tribunals decision is correct. The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings reject all petitioner contentions affirming Industrial Tribunal award under Art.136 review

precedents.citation: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee in this connection relied on Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd. where it was observed at p. 1018- It is, of companyrse, indisputable that  apart from statutory provision to the companytrary  the benefit of a companytract entered into by A to render personal service to X cannot be transferred by X to Y without As companysent, which is the same thing as saying that, in order to produce the desired result,, the old

precedents.case_name: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: apart from statutory provision to the contrary the benefit of a contract entered into by A to render personal service to X cannot be transferred by X to Y without A's consent
precedents.cited_holding: It is, of course, indisputable that apart from statutory provision to the contrary the benefit of a contract entered into by A to render personal service to X cannot be transferred by X to Y without A's consent, which is the same thing as saying that, in order to produce the desired result, the old contract between A and X would have to be terminated by notice or by mutual consent and a new contract of service entered into by agreement between A and Y.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the tribunals decision is companyrect. The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; Industrial Tribunal's award upheld; appellants held to be employees of the Corporation from August 1, 1953, with no rights against Scindias or alternative benefits.

We are therefore of opinion that the tribunals decision is companyrect. The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.
